body.p: Sooda (Simple Object-Oriented Data Access) is an Object-To-Relational Mapping software for the .NET environment. It is a code generator, which can to generate entire Data Access Layer for your application.
Each class that's generated as part of the DAL typically corresponds to a database table, its properties map to database columns and relationships map to object references and collections.

ul.li: mapping one or more tables to a class
one-to-many and many-to-many relationships mapped as strongly typed collections
differential serialization and deserialization of uncommitted changes (enables long-running transactions)
strongly typed query language (based on C# operator overloading)
vertical partitioning of data (load-on-demand for large columns)

body.p: The following development tools/build environments are supported:

ul.li: Microsoft SQL Server 2000, 2005 (including MSDE and SQL Server Express Edition)

body.p: In order to use Sooda in your project you need to have a working database. We'll be using Microsoft SQL Server and the Northwind database. We'll also need to provide Sooda with the following information:

ol.li: Mapping schema that describes the mapping between tables/columns in your database and classes/properties. It is stored in an XML file, usually named SoodaSchema.xml.
Code generation parameters which specify various aspects of code generation. The settings are stored in an XML file with .soodaproject extension.
Runtime configuration parameters such as database connection string, connection type and SQL dialect - typically stored in your Application.exe.config

body.p: In addition, you need to make a small modification to your database (namely add a table that will manage primary keys). The following sections will describe the required setup in detail.

Sooda comes with a wizard for VS.NET 2003 and a project template for Visual Studio 2005 which give you a ready-to-run Sooda environment. You should use it now to create a console application named "SoodaNorthwind".
Assuming you've created a project using the provided wizard you should have a SoodaSchema.xml file in your project. This is a place where you should put the mapping schema. You can do it in two ways:

ul.li: the hard way - manually editing the file. Sooda comes with an XML schema file that installs in Visual Studio to provide Intellisense for editing the configuration files.

the easy way - usign a tool to generate the file for you. Manual editing may still be required for cases that cannot be deduced by the tool, but in general this apprach lets you create a provisional schema very quickly.

body.p: In this tutorial we'll take the latter approach and use a command-line tool that's called SoodaSchemaTool. Future versions of Sooda might add user-friendly wrappers to this tool, but today we need to use the command line.
